out that such a test is much more stringent than the comparisons between the results derive
the PF and experiments because the same interaction potential is used in both calculation

Novoselov, K.S.; Geim, A.K.; Morozov, S.V.; Jiang, D.; Zhang, Y.; Dubonos, S.V.; Grigorieva, I.V.; Firsov,

A silicene grain of four silicon hexagons on the Ag (111) surface with a deposited Si atom
). The free energy for the zigzag adherence and armchair
In summary, DIAwas developed to calculate the free energy (or PF) of 2Dmaterials on a substrate,
and the high calculation precision was validated by MD simulations. It should be pointed out that
such a test is much more stringent than the comparisons between the results derived fromthe PF and
experiments because the same interaction potential is used in both calculations of the PF and the MD
simulations, while the potential may not correctly describe the realistic interactions between atoms
concerned in the experiment. As for the e
ciency, DIA works at least four orders of magnitude faster
cient method, ANS, developed previously, and enables calculations of the free energy
based on ab initio calculations to predict the optimal conditions for novel 2D materials’ growth on a
substrate, which would greatly shorten the way to experimental realization.
Conceptualization, X.-J.N.; funding acquisition, T.-C.W.; methodology, Y.-P.L., B.-Y.N.,
L.-C.G., and X.-J.N.; supervision, T.-C.W. and X.-J.N.; writing, original draft, Y.-P.L., T.-C.W., and X.-J.N.
The work is supported by National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant No. 21727801.
The authors state that there is no conﬂict of interest.

ect in atomically thin carbon ﬁlms.
